questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DIPLOMA LEVEL : BUSINESS ANALYTICS (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

options.option_text: REJECT the NULL HYPOTHESIS and conclude that the number of defectsFOLLOWS a poisson distribution
DO NOT REJECT the NULL HYPOTHESIS and conclude that the number ofdefects FOLLOWS a poisson distribution

DO NOT REJECT the NULL HYPOTHESIS and conclude that the number ofdefects DOES NOT FOLLOW a poisson distribution

DO NOT REJECT the ALTERNATIVE HYPOTHESIS and conclude that the numberof defects FOLLOWS a poisson distribution

questions.question_text_1: In Figure-3 the customer wants to decide between the products O1 & O2, and x denotes the coordinates of the ideal product. Which of the following is/are true?

In Figure-3 the customer wants to decide between the products O1 & O2, and x denotes the coordinates of the ideal product. Which of the following is/are true?

options.option_text: Customers will prefer O1 when d2>d1
Customers will prefer O2 when d1<d2
Both Customers will prefer O1 when d2>d1 & Customers will prefer O2 whend1<d2

questions.question_text_1: There are 7 business units and you are using the DEA to compare them. You solve the LP for business unit 5. You find from the constraint expression that business unit 1 has obtained an efficiency of 1 and business unit 2 has obtained an efficiency of 1 with the optimal weights of business unit 5. Which of the following statements is correct? (choose all that is/are applicable)
question_texts: There are 7 business units and you are using the DEA to compare them. You solve the LP for business unit 5. You find from the constraint expression that business unit 1 has obtained an efficiency of 1 and business unit 2 has obtained an efficiency of 1 with the optimal weights of business unit 5. Which of the following statements is correct? (choose all that is/are applicable)

questions.question_text_1: In DEA, when can the Linear Programming model be used for calculating the weights of efficiency (weighted outputs/weighted inputs)? (choose all that is/are applicable)
question_texts: In DEA, when can the Linear Programming model be used for calculating the weights of efficiency (weighted outputs/weighted inputs)? (choose all that is/are applicable)

options.option_text: After converting the ratio into the linear objective function
By setting a constraint on the efficiency of all DMUs to be lesser than or equalto 1

questions.question_text_1:
(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

A survey was conducted among 100 students who participated in all events at IITMs recent “Saarang” event. The students were asked to rate various aspects of their experience on a scale of “-5 to +5”, where “-5” indicates a very negative experience and “+5” indicates a very positive experience. The average student rating for each event was taken across four key parameters: “Event Ambience”, “Fairness of Event Judges”, “Event Conduct”, “Event Prize Money”. The target variable was “Event Performance” which measures the overall performance of each event. 
Based on the collected data, a correlation matrix as specified in Table-2 is obtained for the independent variables. With this information, answer the given sub-questions

(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

The average student rating for each event was taken across four key parameters: “Event Ambience”, “Fairness of Event Judges”, “Event Conduct”, “Event Prize Money”. The target variable was “Event Performance” which measures the overall performance of each event. 
Based on the collected data, a correlation matrix as specified in Table-2 is obtained for the independent variables. With this information, answer the given sub-questions

questions.question_text_1: There are six business units. There are two outputs and one input under consideration. You are solving the optimization problem for business unit 3, and you find that the efficiency is 0.8. You see that the dual variables corresponding to the constraints of business units 2 and 5 are non-zero, and the dual variables corresponding to the constraints of other units are zero. The dual variables corresponding to the constraints of business units 2 and 5 are 0.5 and 0.3, respectively. Based on Table 6, answers the given sub-questions

The dual variables corresponding to the constraints of business units 2 and 5 are 0.5 and 0.3, respectively. Based on Table 6, answers the given sub-questions

questions.question_text_1:
(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

An insurance company believes that people can be divided into two classes: “Class-1: Those who are accident prone” and “Class-2: Those who are not accident prone”. The company’s statistics show that an accident-prone person will have an accident at sometime within a faxed 1-year period with probability 0.4, whereas this probability decreases to 0.2 for a person who is not accident prone. It is assumed that 30 percent of the human population is accident prone. Given this information, answer the sub-questions
question_texts:
(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

An insurance company believes that people can be divided into two classes: “Class-1: Those who are accident prone” and “Class-2: Those who are not accident prone”. The company’s statistics show that an accident-prone person will have an accident at sometime within a faxed 1-year period with probability 0.4, whereas this probability decreases to 0.2 for a person who is not accident prone. It is assumed that 30 percent of the human population is accident prone. Given this information, answer the sub-questions

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Diploma in Business Analytics (Computer-Based Exam)**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Core Topics & Key Concepts**
### **A. Probability & Statistical Distributions**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Symmetry in Distributions**:
   - **Symmetric Distributions**: Normal, Uniform, Standard Normal.
   - **Asymmetric Distributions**: Poisson, Binomial (unless p=0.5), Exponential.
   - **Key Insight**: Poisson is **right-skewed** (asymmetric).

2. **Empirical Distribution**:
   - Built using:
     - **Sample Data** (observed values).
     - **PDF/PMF** (Probability Density/Mass Function).
     - **Summary Statistics** (mean, variance, etc.).

3. **Hypothesis Testing (Chi-Square Test for Poisson)**:
   - **Null Hypothesis (H₀)**: Data follows a Poisson distribution.
   - **Test Statistic**:
     \[
     \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}
     \]
     where \(O_i\) = observed frequency, \(E_i\) = expected frequency (Poisson).
   - **Decision Rule**:
     - If \(\chi^2 > \chi^2_{\alpha, df}\), **reject H₀** (data does **not** follow Poisson).
     - Otherwise, **fail to reject H₀**.
   - **Degrees of Freedom (df)**:
     \[
     df = \text{number of bins} - 1 - \text{estimated parameters}
     \]
     (For Poisson, 1 parameter: λ).

4. **Poisson Distribution**:
   - **PMF**:
     \[
     P(X = k) = \frac{e^{-\lambda} \lambda^k}{k!}, \quad k = 0, 1, 2, \dots
     \]
   - **Mean & Variance**: \(E[X] = Var(X) = \lambda\).

---

### **B. Regression Analysis**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Linear Regression Model**:
   \[
   Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \epsilon
   \]
   - **Interpretation**:
     - \(\beta_0\) = Intercept (market size if \(X=0\)).
     - \(\beta_1\) = Slope (change in \(Y\) per unit \(X\)).

2. **Elasticity of Demand**:
   \[
   E_d = \beta_1 \times \frac{P}{Q}
   \]
   - **Interpretation**:
     - \(|E_d| > 1\) → **Elastic** (demand sensitive to price).
     - \(|E_d| < 1\) → **Inelastic** (demand insensitive to price).

3. **Coefficient of Determination (\(R^2\))**:
   \[
   R^2 = \frac{SS_{Regression}}{SS_{Total}} = 1 - \frac{SS_{Residual}}{SS_{Total}}
   \]
   - Measures **% of variance in \(Y\) explained by \(X\)**.

4. **Adjusted \(R^2\)**:
   \[
   \text{Adjusted } R^2 = 1 - \left( \frac{(1 - R^2)(n-1)}{n-p-1} \right)
   \]
   - Penalizes extra predictors.

5. **Standard Error of Coefficients**:
   - Increases with **multicollinearity** (high correlation between predictors).

---

### **C. Conjoint Analysis**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Part-Worth Utilities**:
   - Utility contribution of **each attribute level**.
   - Example: If a product has attributes \(A\) and \(B\) with levels \(A_1, A_2\) and \(B_1, B_2\), part-worths are \(U(A_1), U(A_2), U(B_1), U(B_2)\).

2. **Pairwise Comparison**:
   - If attributes are **continuous**, use **optimization** (e.g., gradient descent) to estimate utilities.

3. **Ideal Point Model**:
   - Customers prefer products **closest to their ideal point** in attribute space.
   - **Distance Metric**: Euclidean distance \(d = \sqrt{(x_1 - o_1)^2 + (x_2 - o_2)^2}\).
   - **Preference Rule**: Choose product with **smallest distance** to ideal.

---

### **D. Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Efficiency Score**:
   \[
   \text{Efficiency} = \frac{\text{Weighted Output}}{\text{Weighted Input}} \leq 1
   \]
   - **Efficient DMU**: Score = 1.
   - **Inefficient DMU**: Score < 1.

2. **Linear Programming (LP) Formulation**:
   - **Objective**: Maximize efficiency for a DMU.
   - **Constraints**:
     - All DMUs must have efficiency ≤ 1.
     - Weights must be **non-negative**.

3. **Dual Variables (Shadow Prices)**:
   - Non-zero dual variables indicate **reference units** (efficient DMUs used as benchmarks).

4. **Output/Input Projections**:
   - For an inefficient DMU, projected outputs/inputs are **weighted combinations of reference units**.

---

### **E. Logistic Regression**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Logit Model**:
   \[
   \ln\left(\frac{P(Y=1)}{1 - P(Y=1)}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \dots + \beta_p X_p
   \]
   - \(P(Y=1)\) = Probability of **positive class** (e.g., loan approval).

2. **Odds Ratio**:
   \[
   \text{Odds} = \frac{P(Y=1)}{1 - P(Y=1)} = e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \dots + \beta_p X_p}
   \]
   - **Interpretation of \(\beta_i\)**:
     - If \(\beta_i > 0\): Increase in \(X_i\) **increases odds** of \(Y=1\).
     - If \(\beta_i < 0\): Increase in \(X_i\) **decreases odds** of \(Y=1\).

3. **Performance Metrics**:
   - **Precision** (for class 1):
     \[
     \text{Precision} = \frac{TP}{TP + FP}
     \]
   - **Sensitivity (Recall)**:
     \[
     \text{Sensitivity} = \frac{TP}{TP + FN}
     \]
   - **Specificity**:
     \[
     \text{Specificity} = \frac{TN}{TN + FP}
     \]

---

### **F. Probability & Bayesian Inference**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Total Probability Theorem**:
   \[
   P(A) = P(A|B_1)P(B_1) + P(A|B_2)P(B_2) + \dots + P(A|B_n)P(B_n)
   \]

2. **Bayes’ Theorem**:
   \[
   P(B_i|A) = \frac{P(A|B_i)P(B_i)}{P(A)}
   \]
   - Example: Probability a policyholder is **accident-prone** given they had an accident.

---

## **2. Key Equations Summary**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 | **Interpretation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Poisson PMF**         | \(P(X=k) = \frac{e^{-\lambda} \lambda^k}{k!}\)                              | Probability of \(k\) events in a fixed interval.                                  |
| **Chi-Square Test**     | \(\chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}\)                                  | Test for goodness-of-fit (e.g., Poisson).                                        |
| **Linear Regression**   | \(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \epsilon\)                                     | Models relationship between \(Y\) and \(X\).                                     |
| **Elasticity**          | \(E_d = \beta_1 \times \frac{P}{Q}\)                                       | Measures sensitivity of demand to price.                                          |
| **R-Squared**          | \(R^2 = 1 - \frac{SS_{Residual}}{SS_{Total}}\)                              | % of variance in \(Y\) explained by \(X\).                                        |
| **DEA Efficiency**      | \(\text{Efficiency} = \frac{\text{Weighted Output}}{\text{Weighted Input}}\) | Measures relative efficiency of Decision Making Units (DMUs).                     |
| **Logistic Regression** | \(\ln\left(\frac{P}{1-P}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X\)                    | Models probability of binary outcomes.                                             |
| **Bayes’ Theorem**     | \(P(B|A) = \frac{P(A|B)P(B)}{P(A)}\)                                        | Updates probability based on new evidence.                                        |

---

```mermaid
    C --> G[Logit Model: log(P/1-P) = β₀ + β₁X]

    I --> K[Sensitivity]
    I --> L[Specificity]
```

```mermaid
    F --> G[Maximize Efficiency]
    F --> H[Constraints: All DMUs ≤1]

```


```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Hypothesis Testing] --> B[Define H₀ and H₁]

    D --> F[Calculate χ²]

    G --> I[Fail to Reject Otherwise]
```

### **Graph 6: Logistic Regression Interpretation**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Logistic Regression] --> B[Coefficients β₀, β₁, ...]
    B --> C[Odds Ratio: e^βᵢ]
    C --> D[If βᵢ > 0: Increases Odds]
    C --> E[If βᵢ < 0: Decreases Odds]
    A --> F[Performance Metrics]
    F --> G[Precision: TP / (TP + FP)]
    F --> H[Sensitivity: TP / (TP + FN)]
    F --> I[Specificity: TN / (TN + FP)]
```

---
## **4. Exam Tips**
1. **Poisson Distribution**:
   - Always check for **right skewness** (asymmetric).
   - For Chi-Square tests, **bins with expected frequency <5 should be merged**.

2. **Regression**:
   - **Intercept (\(\beta_0\))** = Market size when \(X=0\).
   - **Elasticity** depends on **current price and quantity**.

3. **DEA**:
   - **Efficient DMUs** lie on the **frontier**.
   - **Dual variables** indicate **reference units** for inefficient DMUs.

4. **Logistic Regression**:
   - **Coefficients** affect the **log-odds**.
   - **Odds Ratio** = \(e^{\beta_i}\) (multiplicative effect).

5. **Conjoint Analysis**:
   - **Part-worths** sum to **total utility**.
   - **Ideal point** minimizes distance in attribute space.

6. **Bayes’ Theorem**:
   - Use **prior probabilities** and **likelihoods** to update beliefs.

---
This summary covers **all major topics** in the exam. Focus on **equations, interpretations, and decision rules** (e.g., when to reject \(H_0\) in Chi-Square tests). The Mermaid graphs help visualize **concept relationships** for quick revision. Good luck!
